subject: Web3
title: Using a Hardware Wallet
description: A short lesson to help you apply Using a Hardware Wallet.

hook.text: A hardware wallet stores your private keys on a physical device that never connects to the internet.

buildup.text: Devices like Ledger and Trezor keep keys offline. Transactions must be physically confirmed by pressing a button.

discovery.text: Even if your computer is compromised, a hardware wallet protects your keys. The hacker can't reach what's offline.

twist.text: Ledger faced backlash for announcing a cloud backup feature. Users buy hardware wallets specifically to avoid the cloud.

climax.text: A hardware wallet won't protect against signing malicious transactions. You still need to verify what you approve.

punchline.text: Keep your keys offline. A $70 device protects millions.

quiz.question: Why are hardware wallets considered secure?
options: Private keys are stored on a device that never connects to the internet
